headline: Martin Luther King Jr. Speaks at Grinnell
title: The Liberal Arts College in a World of Change
description: During a three-day long convocation, titled a "The Liberal Arts College in a World of Change", Martin Luther King Jr. spoke to a crowd of 4,000 people at Darby Gym. MLK’s speech was especially impactful to Black students on campus. At the time, only 10 Black students were enrolled at Grinnell College. 6 months later, MLk was assassinated on Thursday, 4 April 1968 in Memphis, TN.
subject: Life at Grinnell for Black Students

headline: CBS is Created
title: CBS Cheerleaders, 1968
description: After MLK's death, Black students at Grinnell formed the Concerned Black Students (CBS). With only 10 Black students enrolled in 1968, CBS provided Black students with much-needed community. Additionally, the CBS became a powerhouse for advocating for campus-wide changes to better meet the needs of Black students. CBS worked closely with other organizations, like the Young, Gifted and Black Gospel Choir, to promote the wellness of Black students. Picture description: CBS cheerleaders, 1968. Front to back: Micki Weston, Unknown, Shirley, Linda Copeland.
subject: Concerned Black Students (CBS)

creator: Scarlet & Black
headline: CBS advocates for a Black Library
title: CBS advocates for a Black Library
description: This article reports the first time that CBS approached the Student Government Association (SGA) for $400 dollars (about $3,618 dollars in 2024) to create a Black Library and a Black student newspaper. The article details 6 other proposals that CBS wanted to enact, many of which were later reflected in the Black Manifesto.
subject: Concerned Black Students (CBS);Burling Library;Black Library
people: Ernest T. Weston ‘71; Debbie Green; Merryll Penson; Frank Thomas; Gregg Coggs '69

headline: First Black Martyr's Weekend
title: Black Martyrs' Weekend (April 3, 1969)
description:
On the first anniversary of Dr. Martin Luther
King, Jr’s Assassination, CBS organized the first Black Martyr's Weekend. The event was designed to honor Dr. King and others
who died fighting for
racial justice. The event included a speech by Dr. Nathan Hare, the chairman of the Black Student Party at San Francisco State College; a panel discussion titled "In Defense of
Black People — The Black Panther
Party" which featured three members of the Des
Moines Black Panther Party; a lecture by Dr. Charles H. Nichols, a visiting professor of History and American Studies at Grinnell, titled “Martin Luther
King, Jr. and the Present American
Mood”; a dance performance by CBS members; a dance headlined by the Jackson 5; and a speech by William Strickland, a New York psychology
gist and founder of the Northern Student
Movement.
subject: Life at Grinnell for Black Students;Concerned Black Students (CBS)

headline: Grinnell introduces “African and Afro-American Studies” program
description: This is the first iteration of a curriculum dedicated to the study of Africa and African-Americans at Grinnell College and was a result of a proposal created by CBS. In addition to the studies program, the proposal also asked for a scholarship program for Black students, and the recruitment of (preferably Black) faculty and staff to develop the studies program (S&B: September 13th 1969: Page 8).

headline:
CBS successfully
petitions for the
creation of the Black
Cultural Center
description: CBS successfully petitions the Board of Trustees for the creation of the Black Cultural Center, now known as the Conney M. Kimbo Black Cultural Center. The BCC would become a critical community space for Black students and CBS would use this space to coordinate their activities and activism.

headline: Grinnell College Closes as a Response to the Kent State Shootings
description: On May 4th, 1970, The Ohio National Guard open fired on a group of unarmed student activist protesting the Vietnam War and the US’s expansion into Cambodia. The Ohio National Guardsmen killed 4 students and wounded 9 others. Grinnell’s campus was rocked by the shooting. By May 5th, students occupied the local ROTC building. By May 8th, faculty voted to cancel classes, exams, and graduation commencement. “As a way of explanation, College President Glenn Legett wrote, ‘the College [could not] continue to carry on its normal and traditional functions in the next two weeks’ given the polarization on campus.” (S&B: February 20th, 2023; “History Takeover: The first time graduation was cancelled, 1970”). This event highlights the tensions and activism that was building on campus at the time.

headline: "Yonkers Proposal" for On-Campus Housing for Black Students
description: In addition to the BCC, which can only house a few students, Black students along with Dean Kimbo, request the implementation of the "Younker Proposal." This housing plan, in which Black students were spread out across Younker, would allow Black students to live among one another and foster sense of belonging.

creator: Henry, George T.
headline: Black Cultural Center is Built
title: Denise L. Iverson ’74 and Roxane D. Brown ’74 in the Black Cultural Center
description: The creation of the BCC was one of the first goals of CBS. While it initially served as gathering space, it also became student housing when there was a shortage of dorm rooms. During the 1971 Burling Take Over, the 7th demand of the Black Manifesto stated that “because of the enrollment and the programs of CBS,we feel that the present Cultural Center is insufficient, therefore we demand a house large enough to accommodate the programs of CBS”.
Source: Life at Grinnell for Black Students;Concerned Black Students (CBS);Black Manifesto Demands
subject: Denise L. Iverson ’74; Roxane D. Brown ’74
language: Copyright to this work is held by the author(s), in accordance with United States copyright law (USC 17). Readers of this work have certain rights as defined by the law, including but not limited to fair use (17 USC 107 et seq.).

headline: Grinnell discontinues "African and Afro-American Studies" program
description: Due to a lack of a formal structure and consistent support, the “African and Afro-American Studies” curriculum never completely formed. Most students interested in majoring in this area relied on the independent majors system. However, new guidelines on independent majors severely impacted students ability to to complete majors that Grinnell did not offer sufficient course for.

creator: Joint Board of House of Presidents
headline: Students Respond: NBC Manifesto
title: Memo from the Joint Board of House Presidents
description: This memo was sent by the Joint Board of the House of Presidents after the Burling Take Over. It references the tensions on campus between black and white members of Grinnell, and that all member of the Grinnell college community should respect the negotiations to alleviate the present tensions. The memo refers to the "NBC Manifesto", which was a racist satire of CBS’s Black Manifesto distributed soon after the take over.
subject: Burling Library Take Over of '71 & '72;Reactions to the Take Over

creator: Concerned Black Students
headline: The Burling Library Takeover
title: CBS Manifesto and Minutes of Faculty Meeting regarding the Manifesto
description: On the morning of November 29th, 1971, over 50 students occupied Burling Library. The students chained the doors, prevented white patrons from entering, and distributed The Black Manifesto; a list of 10 demands designed to improve campus life for Black students and faculty.This includes two versions of the Concerned Black Students' (CBS) Manifesto, the second of which was submitted to the college as a list of demands on the part of black students on campus. A special faculty meeting was held to discuss the demands, the minutes from which also appear here.
subject: Burling Library Take Over of '71 & '72;Black Manifesto Demands;Concerned Black Students (CBS);Black Library
people: Glenn Leggett, Grinnell President  1965-1975;  Waldo “Wally” Walker, Dean; Lawrence Wright
rights: Copyright to this work is held by the author(s), in accordance with United States copyright law (USC 17). Readers of this work have certain rights as defined by the law, including but not limited to fair use (17 USC 107 et seq.).

headline: Special Meeting of the Faculty to Discuss CBS Demands
description: Three days after the Takeover, the Faculty convened for a special meeting to discuss the demands detailed in the Black Manifesto. Several immediate measures were approved such as the installation of a refrigerator and cooking ranges in the BBC to address some of the SAGA-related food issues, assigning a CBS student auditor to distribute CBS funds, establishing the policy to include a Black spokesperson in any official meeting concerning the Black community on campus, and creating the Admission Board for Black Students. Additionally, ad hoc committees were formed to address the remaining issues including the Black Studies Major. The faculty also agreed to put the current bibliography of “African/Afro-American Studies” books on open reserve and that librarian Mary Gae Wyly would work with representatives of CBS to further developed this collection.

creator: Concerned Black Students
headline: Proposal for Black Library
title: Proposal for Black Library
description: This proposal was sent three months after the Burling Takeover. This document states that while attempts were made to meet the 10th demand of the Black Manifesto (“The institution of a Black Library with all audio-visual equipment that will aid in the academic survival of all black students”), the 50 books that made up the Black Library at that time was not satisfactory. The document outlines more detailed demands like collection development responsibilities, necessary equipment, financial and maintenance considerations, etc. The document also provides more details as to why a Black Library is needed, included the need to “give credit to an important cultural contribution that has thus been overlooked”.
subject: Burling Library;Burling Library Take Over of '71 & '72;Concerned Black Students (CBS);Black Library

headline: Enlarge the Black Library
title: "Enlarge the Black Library/" Scarlet & Black February 11 1972
description: The Scarlet and Black article “Enlarge the black library?” discussed the debate around the size of the Black library collection and included a sketch of three shelves the first iteration of the Black Library occupied.

headline: The Second Burling Takeover
title:
Second Take over of Burling Library Twentieth
Century Room
description:
Members of CBS felt that many of the promised made to address CBS’s demands were not being fulfilled. To encourage more momentum, students staged a second demonstration. This time, students reshelved books that should be included in the Black Library and placed them in the Twentieth
Century Room, which is where CBS wanted the Black Library to be located. Wally Walker is pictured speaking to CBS students in the Twentieth
Century Room, asking them to leave as their actions violated federal laws.
subject: Burling Library Take Over of '71 & '72;Concerned Black Students (CBS);Burling Library

creator: Scarlet and Black;
headline: CBS Circulation Demonstration
title: Scarlet & Black March 3, 1972
description: A lesser known example of activism for the Black Library is the Circulation Demonstration of February 29th, 1972. About 40 Black students checked out over 800 books between 10 and 11 pm. All the books were reported to be relevant to Black Studies and were loaded into a van that went to the BCC. Earlier that day, the library received an anonymous call informing them that some sort of demonstration was going to take place that night over the College’s decision to fire Alan Nasser. Librarian Henry Alden reported to Dean Wally Walker that the students did not violate any library rules in this demonstration, but did keep the library unusually busy.
subject: Burling Library;Life at Grinnell for Black Students;Black Library

title: Burling pre-renovation
description: The Twentieth Century Room became the home of the Black Library.

headline: Grinnell Establishes a Black Studies Major
description: In accordance with the Black Manifesto demands, the college establishes an interdisciplinary major in black studies in 1972. It was a 36-credit major and included courses in anthropology, economics, English, history, music, political science, and sociology.

creator: Scarlet and Black;
headline: Plans to Expand Black Library
title: "Plan Black Library Expansion" Scarlet & Black September 22, 1972
description: This article reports that the library assembled 900+ books for the Black Library that will be housed in the Twentieth Century Room. Librarian Mary Gae Wyly is mentioned as the librarian primarily working on the collection. Other details include the collection development efforts, funding, potential events, and Leggat's guidelines for the space. Librarian Christopher Mckee states that he would really appreciate suggestions for the library. A photo of the Black Library is included.

creator: Scarlet and Black; Irma McClaurin; Ben Z Dreen
headline: The Black Library Becomes a Event Space
title: "Barlow: Vibrant, Varied Emotions" Scarlet and Black December 8 1972 page 2
description: The Black Library became a space for events that featured Black scholarship and excellence. The article, "Barlow: Vibrant, Varied Emotions" Article by Irma McClaurin about Barlow's public reading in the Black Library, includes picture of the Black Library behind Barlow.

headline: The Admission Board for Black Students is Dissolved
description:
The Black Admissions Board is dissolved after a letter from U.S. Department of Health, Education, and Welfare deems it
“unacceptable”. Pictured is Maurice ""Mo"" Hunt, Coach and Admissions Counselor for the Black Admissions Board until its dissolvement. He wanted to increase the Black student population from the 5% in 1973 "to at least 10%" (S&B April 6th, 1973 page 8). As of 2025, the Black student population of Grinnell College has never reached 10% of the total student population.

headline: STOPIT Campaign
description: Six years after the Burling Library Takeover, CBS revealed its plans to address racial issues that were still unresolved. The STOPIT (Students and Teachers Opposed to Practices Intolerable and Timid) Campaign aimed to alleviate the concerning lack of non-white faculty, students and studies at Grinnell College. This campaign focused on communication with the student body and administration. (S&B October 7th, 1977; Page 1)

headline: The Black Studies Major is discontinued
description: The Black Studies Major is discontinued due to lack of student interest and institutional support. Charles Davis, Chairman of the Black Studies Program, stated that he was “handling the load alone” as few Black professors were hired (*S&B*: March 4, 1977 “The black Grinnell Experience”). At the time, The S&B reported that just 10 students graduated with majors in black studies from 1972 to 1979. Rico Williams ‘75, pictured, was one of those few students. The major is replaced with “Afro-American studies interdisciplinary concentration” (*S&B*: May 11th, 1979. “The ‘F’ is back”).

headline: Black Library Relocated
description: When Burling Library is renovated in 1982, the Black Library was moved to the Second Floor, where it remains today.

headline: CBS's 1995 Silent Protest and the Creation of Africana Studies Concentration
description: In response to a racist editorial in the S&B and the use of racial slurs on KDIC and at basketball game, CBS members demonstrated by wearing all black, taping their mouths shut and standing in the back of their morning classes. In response to this demonstration, the college established a new Africana studies concentration.

headline: The Black Library as an Art Exhibit
description: By the 1990's, the space around the Black Library was used as exhibit space, typically featuring Grinnell College Museum of Art's Black art collections from the US, Africa and other locations. The Hemba Stool pictured here was one such item.
rights: Copyright to this work is held by the author(s), in accordance with United States copyright law (USC 17). Readers of this work have certain rights as defined by the law, including but not limited to fair use (17 USC 107 et seq.).

headline: Africana studies concentration discontinued
description: According to Grinnell Magazine, "From 1999 to 2005, there were a total of 20 students who graduated with an Africana studies concentration." "After seeing zero interest in upper-level Africana courses and limited interest in introductory classes, the faculty, including Gibel Mevorach and Scott, suggested dissolving Africana studies as an interim move toward something more comprehensive." "“The administration had nothing to do with this decision. This was not a problem of not enough faculty to teach a course — there were no students,” Gibel Mevorach says. “GWSS absorbed most students of color interested in diversity who were interested, as well, in gender studies; and more than a few potential recruits were sociology majors.”

headline: Remembering the Burling Takeover: 2006
title: Burling Library Takeover Commemoration, 2006
description: This photograph was taken in 2006 at an event commemorating the 1971 takeover of Burling Library by CBS (Concerned Black Students). Fifty-five students with candles, representing the fifty-five students who took over Burling in 1971, marched from the Black Culture Center (BCC) to Burling. Once at Burling, the group read the Black Manifesto, enjoyed the Young, Gifted, and Black Gospel Choir’s performance, held a poetry reading, and discussed the ways the Burling Takeover changed Grinnell.

headline: Remembering the Burling Takeover: 2009 Site-Specific Dance
title: The Life of a Library Text: Grinnell College's Black Library - Takeover Dance 2
description: In 2009, Latona Giwa '09 and Courtney Moore '11 staged a site-specific dance event in and around the Black Library. The performers based their dance on the history of the Black Library and passed out copies of the Black Manifesto.

headline: College enrolls 100 Black students
description: 43 years after CBS demanded that Grinnell College enrolls "no less than 200" Black students, Grinnell College enrolls 100 Black students for the first time in its history.
